questions.question: What does ISO actually control in a digital camera?
options: The physical sensitivity of the sensor
The amount of light the lens transmits
The amplification of the sensor's signal after capture
The color temperature of the image
questions.reviewHint: ISO boosts (amplifies) the sensor signal; it doesn't change the lens or sensor physics.

questions.question: Which sequence shows full-stop ISO steps?
You go from ISO 200 to 400, keep aperture at f/8, and started at 1/125s. Which shutter keeps the same exposure?
questions.reviewHint: Doubling ISO requires halving shutter time to keep exposure constant.

questions.question: As ISO increases (all else equal), which artifact increases most?
Which is most likely a camera's base/native ISO?
questions.reviewHint: Most modern cameras have base ISO around 100 (some 64).

questions.question: You're at 1/60s, f/4, ISO 100. To freeze action at 1/250s (two stops faster) while keeping f/4, what ISO gives the same exposure?
In Aperture Priority with Auto ISO (min shutter 1/250s, max ISO not yet reached), what does the camera change first as light drops?
options: It slows below the min shutter
questions.reviewHint: Auto ISO increases ISO to maintain the min shutter until limits are hit.

questions.question: Which statement about ISO and dynamic range is most accurate?
options: Higher ISO generally reduces dynamic range
Lower ISO always increases shadow noise
questions.reviewHint: Raising ISO usually lowers DR, especially in highlights.

questions.question: On an ISO-invariant camera, which approach best preserves highlights while yielding similar noise?
options: Raise ISO in-camera instead of pushing in post
Shoot at lower ISO to protect highlights, then brighten in post
Use Auto ISO with +2 EV compensation
questions.reviewHint: With ISO-invariant sensors, pushing in post is similar in noise while protecting highlights.

questions.question: With manual flash power fixed, increasing ISO from 400 to 800 will:
options: Brighten ambient but not flash exposure
Brighten both ambient and flash-lit areas by one stop
questions.reviewHint: ISO raises sensitivity to all light sources; both brighten one stop.

questions.question: Which is the best practice to minimize high-ISO noise?
options: Always shoot base ISO, even if motion blurs
Use the lowest ISO that still gives the shutter speed/aperture you need
Use maximum ISO and denoise later

questions.question: Start at 1/50s, f/2.8, ISO 100. You change to ISO 400 (↑2 stops) and f/5.6 (↓2 stops). To keep the same exposure, which shutter speed?
questions.reviewHint: +2 ISO and −2 aperture cancel; shutter stays the same.
